body:
Raised Christian. Became an atheist when going through high school and college. 

Now after seeing all this covid and the great reset / new world order stuff going on and how the Bible seems to have warned about this stuff... I feel like I am being pulled back into it.

The reason I'm asking for good sources is because it seems to me that a lot of Christianity has become "weak". Too tolerant, liberal, and afraid to stand up for their faith. Too "nice guy - ish" if you know what I mean.
body_html:
Raised Christian. Became an atheist when going through high school and college.

Now after seeing all this covid and the great reset / new world order stuff going on and how the Bible seems to have warned about this stuff... I feel like I am being pulled back into it.

The reason I'm asking for good sources is because it seems to me that a lot of Christianity has become "weak". Too tolerant, liberal, and afraid to stand up for their faith. Too "nice guy - ish" if you know what I mean.
title: Returning Christian. What are good sources to learn from?

body: Read up on the Early Church Fathers.
body_html: Read up on the Early Church Fathers.

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

post.title: Returning Christian. What are good sources to learn from?

body: The New Testament of the Bible - as the NT replaces the old. Also, the NT is considerably shorter, so you can get up to speed more quickly. King James Version is considered to be the best version, despite being harder to read.

body:
> The reason I'm asking for good sources is because it seems to me that a lot of Christianity has become "weak"....Too "nice guy - ish" if you know what I mean.

Be careful, this is the excuse everyone uses when they want to be Pharisees. "Jesus said to do this but that's weak so we should do this other thing instead!". It does feel wrong because it goes against every fiber of our DNA and primal urges. But indeed the biblical writers accurately described the flesh as evil and opposed to the spirit.
body_html:

body:
KJV is the *most popular*, not the best. It has a lot more translation errors due to less scholarship access in the days it was published, and faced more pressure from the Anglican and Catholic churches to conform to their doctrines. Beyond that the archaic English is often problematic for a modern reader. However, it does excel in poetry and the artistic aspect of literature (though that could partly be because our brains go "old-fashioned=poetic").

Also there is nothing ever stating the "new testament" replaces the old. Such a thing didn't even exist in the first century. The real problem is that the texts we have today are corrupted from millennia of hand copying, and the books of Moses are actually only partly the original law revealed to Moses; they also contain the Israelites' cultural practices which they tried to pass off as God's law (Jeremiah 8:8). The new testament is no different, though (thank God) a LOT more in the epistles than the gospels, which conveniently are the very books which tend to be ignored by most Christians.
body_html:
KJV is the most popular, not the best. It has a lot more translation errors due to less scholarship access in the days it was published, and faced more pressure from the Anglican and Catholic churches to conform to their doctrines. Beyond that the archaic English is often problematic for a modern reader. However, it does excel in poetry and the artistic aspect of literature (though that could partly be because our brains go "old-fashioned=poetic").

Also there is nothing ever stating the "new testament" replaces the old. Such a thing didn't even exist in the first century. The real problem is that the texts we have today are corrupted from millennia of hand copying, and the books of Moses are actually only partly the original law revealed to Moses; they also contain the Israelites' cultural practices which they tried to pass off as God's law (Jeremiah 8:8). The new testament is no different, though (thank God) a LOT more in the epistles than the gospels, which conveniently are the very books which tend to be ignored by most Christians.

body:
I would start with the gospel of Luke since it's probably the most historically accurate (excluding the first two chapters which are completely made up and added later). Then take a look at the other gospels. Focus on Jesus, and focus on the overarching theme, because there will be some contradictions. And then if you want you can read the other books for some good input by followers.

I would advise checking each passage in the original languages too, especially if something seems suspicious, because by its very nature a translation is biased towards the doctrines of the translators. In some cases, even deliberately, and often almost unanimously.
body_html:
I would start with the gospel of Luke since it's probably the most historically accurate (excluding the first two chapters which are completely made up and added later). Then take a look at the other gospels. Focus on Jesus, and focus on the overarching theme, because there will be some contradictions. And then if you want you can read the other books for some good input by followers.

I would advise checking each passage in the original languages too, especially if something seems suspicious, because by its very nature a translation is biased towards the doctrines of the translators. In some cases, even deliberately, and often almost unanimously.

body: NT doesnt so much replace as fulfill the OT.  OT is all prophecy pointing towards the coming of Christ and His sacrifice on the cross.  Christ's death and fulfillment of the prophets and the law shifted the focus from repentence through obedience to the law, which never worked because no man can keep the law fully, to repentence through faith in His sacrifice and pursuit of His love in our lives.
body_html: NT doesnt so much replace as fulfill the OT. OT is all prophecy pointing towards the coming of Christ and His sacrifice on the cross. Christ's death and fulfillment of the prophets and the law shifted the focus from repentence through obedience to the law, which never worked because no man can keep the law fully, to repentence through faith in His sacrifice and pursuit of His love in our lives.

parent.body: The New Testament of the Bible - as the NT replaces the old. Also, the NT is considerably shorter, so you can get up to speed more quickly. King James Version is considered to be the best version, despite being harder to read.

body:
I will also, as many others here do, encourage you to start with the gospels.  I will suggest John first, as it portrays Jesus as God, while the others were tailored a bit more for the Jews or the Greeks.  

My 2 cents, for what theyre worth, is that that Jesus only seems like a nice guy until you actually read what he said and did.  Dude wove himself a bullwhip then raided the temple to drive out the merchants that had set up shop there.  Told off the pharisees to their faces so bluntly and so often they tried to kill him for it numerous times.  Jesus was not your modern "nice guy."

Edit: Also, if youre of a more philosophical bent, anything CS Lewis wrote is pretty good.  Still, regarding doctrine, I would say, dont listen to what people say, look at what the Bible says.  Take it back to the original Greek and Hebrew with a Concordance.  Our modern society and modern churches have spent the last several centuries twisting its teachings into what people think Christianity is today, but the original texts are still there to be read for themselves, no matter how much people try to twist them.
body_html:
I will also, as many others here do, encourage you to start with the gospels. I will suggest John first, as it portrays Jesus as God, while the others were tailored a bit more for the Jews or the Greeks.

My 2 cents, for what theyre worth, is that that Jesus only seems like a nice guy until you actually read what he said and did. Dude wove himself a bullwhip then raided the temple to drive out the merchants that had set up shop there. Told off the pharisees to their faces so bluntly and so often they tried to kill him for it numerous times. Jesus was not your modern "nice guy."

Edit: Also, if youre of a more philosophical bent, anything CS Lewis wrote is pretty good. Still, regarding doctrine, I would say, dont listen to what people say, look at what the Bible says. Take it back to the original Greek and Hebrew with a Concordance. Our modern society and modern churches have spent the last several centuries twisting its teachings into what people think Christianity is today, but the original texts are still there to be read for themselves, no matter how much people try to twist them.

author.bio: GM of +Clownworld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +Prolife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others
author.bio_html: GM of +ClownWorld +News +Commentary +Conspiracy +Christianity +ProLife +Conservatives +MAGA and a few others

body:
If you’re interested in the more intellectual side, I’d recommend apologetics, cs lewis, and biblical archeology as supplemental material. 

God knew things would be challenging for those going against world that was corrupt and evil and far from Him. He tells us to wear a virtual suit of armor:

“Now my beloved ones, I have saved these most important truths for last: Be supernaturally infused with strength through your life-union with the Lord Jesus. Stand victorious with the force of his explosive power flowing in and through you.

11 Put on God’s complete set of armor provided for us, so that you will be protected as you fight against the evil strategies of the accuser! 12 Your hand-to-hand combat is not with human beings, but with the highest principalities and authorities operating in rebellion under the heavenly realms. For they are a powerful class of demon-gods and evil spirits that hold this dark world in bondage. 13 Because of this, you must wear all the armor that God provides so you’re protected as you confront the slanderer, for you are destined for all things and will rise victorious.

14 Put on truth as a belt to strengthen you to stand in triumph. Put on holiness as the protective armor that covers your heart. 15 Stand on your feet alert, then you’ll always be ready to share the blessings of peace.

16 In every battle, take faith as your wrap-around shield, for it is able to extinguish the blazing arrows coming at you from the evil one! 17–18 Embrace the power of salvation’s full deliverance, like a helmet to protect your thoughts from lies. And take the mighty razor-sharp Spirit-sword of the spoken word of God.”

May God bless you and guide you and be a pillar of strength for you, so you can face the world with confidence and overcome all.
body_html:
If you’re interested in the more intellectual side, I’d recommend apologetics, cs lewis, and biblical archeology as supplemental material.

God knew things would be challenging for those going against world that was corrupt and evil and far from Him. He tells us to wear a virtual suit of armor:

“Now my beloved ones, I have saved these most important truths for last: Be supernaturally infused with strength through your life-union with the Lord Jesus. Stand victorious with the force of his explosive power flowing in and through you.

11 Put on God’s complete set of armor provided for us, so that you will be protected as you fight against the evil strategies of the accuser! 12 Your hand-to-hand combat is not with human beings, but with the highest principalities and authorities operating in rebellion under the heavenly realms. For they are a powerful class of demon-gods and evil spirits that hold this dark world in bondage. 13 Because of this, you must wear all the armor that God provides so you’re protected as you confront the slanderer, for you are destined for all things and will rise victorious.

14 Put on truth as a belt to strengthen you to stand in triumph. Put on holiness as the protective armor that covers your heart. 15 Stand on your feet alert, then you’ll always be ready to share the blessings of peace.

16 In every battle, take faith as your wrap-around shield, for it is able to extinguish the blazing arrows coming at you from the evil one! 17–18 Embrace the power of salvation’s full deliverance, like a helmet to protect your thoughts from lies. And take the mighty razor-sharp Spirit-sword of the spoken word of God.”

May God bless you and guide you and be a pillar of strength for you, so you can face the world with confidence and overcome all.

body: Jesus only used a bullwhip according to John, the last gospel to be composed. The earlier three all record the merchant incident without it, and John is dependent on them meaning the writer added it. Early church fathers also doubted its historicity, understanding it metaphorically.
